I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested support from the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to strengthen policies and delivery modes for social work 
services for the elderly with special difficulties. A fact-finding mission took place in Beijing, the 
PRC in January 2015, and ADB reached an agreement with the Ministry of Civil Affairs (MOCA) 
on  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  costs  and  financing,  implementation  arrangements,  and 
outline terms of reference for consulting services for the technical assistance (TA). The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The main demographic challenges facing the PRC in this century are the dramatic aging 
of its population, scale of internal migration largely driven by urbanization, and new social and 
economic  vulnerabilities  arising  from  these  changes.  The  elderly  with  special  physical, 
psychological, and/or financial difficulties now have more diverse and individualized needs. 
They require a combination of targeted poverty-reduction measures and affordable medical and 
social services. Data on the elderly with special difficulties show that the PRC has 100 million 
living in empty-nest households, 100 million with chronic illnesses, 50 million left behind in the 
countryside alone, 38 million unable to perform daily activities, 23 million stricken in poverty or 
with low income, and 10 million who have lost their only child. The number of elderly aged       
80 years and above has reached about 22.7 million.2 A range of gender-related disparities 
include  women’s  poorer  health  status,  lower  cognitive  performance,  and  poorer  financial 
security than men of similar age. 
 
3.  The  PRC  has  responded  to  overall  elderly  care  needs  with  new  policy  and  legal 
initiatives, including the Twelfth Five-Year Plan for the Development of Social Care Services for 
the Elderly, 2011–2015, and the revised Law on the Protection of the Rights and Interests of the 
Elderly, 2013. Both documents call for developing social services for the elderly, including 
through  (i)  expansion  and  professionalization  of  elderly  care  social  workers,  social  work 
standards, and the social work sector; and (ii) encouragement for government agencies and 
social organizations to engage in delivery of outsourced elderly care social services. These 
documents have been supported by guidance on implementation modalities, including Opinions 
on  Strengthening  the  Development  of  Professional  Social  Workers,  jointly  issued  by 
19 ministries; the Medium- and Long-Term Development Plan for the Development of Social 
Work  Forces,  2011–2020;  and  the  Guidelines  for  Government  Purchase  of  Social  Work 
Services, including the use of state lottery funds toward the procurement of elderly care services 
by social organizations. The reform agenda of the Third Plenary Session of the 18th Central 
Committee of the Chinese Communist Party in November 2013 calls for an acceleration of 
reforms to improve and expand the provision of social services—such as education, health, 
elderly  care,  and  social  protection—allowing  more  benefits  from  development  to  be  more 
equally shared by all. 
 
4.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2011–2015 for the PRC, 
promoting basic social services; and ADB’s Midterm Review of Strategy 2020, with renewed 
emphasis on health and education as part of ADB’s inclusive growth agenda.3 The TA is also

part of a new area of strategic thrusts in ADB’s operations in the PRC to develop services for an

provided several TA projects in the PRC for consolidation of the social assistance (dibao)

delivery.6 Aging will be a critical challenge for sustaining growth, making it more inclusive, and 
providing  social  protection  in  the  region,  as  this  demographic  shift  has  started  in  most 
developing economies in Asia. The aging population represents an important opportunity for 
ADB to provide TA and lending in the coming years. It will also build on findings from ADB’s TA 
for Promoting Market Innovation in Developing Social Infrastructure: Old Age Caring; TA for 
Strategic Elderly Care Services Development in Yichang, on local planning for elderly care in 
Yichang; TA for Strategies for Involving Social Workers in Social Assistance, on strengthening 
social workers to support social assistance recipients in their transition to the labor market; and 
TA  for  Strengthening  Government  and  Social  Organization  Cooperation  for  Rural  Poverty 
Reduction, on outsourcing and social organizations.7 
 
5.  Several key issues require urgent action to promote both professional and community-
based  social  work  and  outsourcing  of  social  services  focused  on  the  elderly  with  special 
difficulties. First, a strong policy framework and guidelines for care of the elderly with special 
difficulties  are  needed.  Second,  a  rewarding  career  path  for  social  workers  needs  to  be 
developed,  starting  with  appropriate  education  and  training,  and  decent  pay  and  working 
conditions. Third, improved government procurement mechanisms, including volunteer incentive 
mechanisms, for services provided to the elderly with special difficulties by social organizations 
engaged in elderly care, community development, or poverty reduction need to be developed, 
particularly in remote or difficult-to-access conditions.8 
 
6.  MOCA has submitted a project proposal to ADB through the Ministry of Finance to 
provide TA to better understand international and national trends in professionalizing social 
work, especially to provide services to the elderly and provide tools to MOCA to standardize, 
monitor, and evaluate social work services for the elderly with special difficulties. This will 
contribute to improving the education and practical experience of social workers and social 
organizations caring for the elderly with special needs, and provide more effective and relevant 
social support and delivery modes. The TA findings will potentially be replicable nationwide.

III.  THE POLICY AND ADVISORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact will be a strengthened policy environment for social work for the elderly, 
primarily for those with special difficulties. The outcome will be policy recommendations on 
strengthening social work services for the elderly with special difficulties. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  An extensive review of international and national experiences and best practices will 
help in the development of guidelines and a broad implementation framework for social work 
service standards for the elderly with special difficulties. The TA will complement this with a 
monitoring and evaluation system on social work services for the elderly with special difficulties. 
The findings from the TA will be used to formulate policy recommendations on strengthening 
social work services for the elderly with special difficulties. 
 
9.  Key activities of the TA will be organized under four outputs: 
 
(i)  Output 1: Study report on national and international experience on social 
work services for the elderly with special difficulties. The TA will review 
national and international literature, and ongoing pilot experiences in the PRC. 
The focus of the study will be on policies, financing, mode and scope of service 
delivery, and quality and safety monitoring. The study report will be disseminated 
to public and private stakeholders, and social organizations. The TA will facilitate 
relevant  field  visits  in  the  PRC  and  an  overseas  study  tour  (tentatively)  in 
Canada, Europe, Japan, the Republic of Korea, or Thailand to study social work 
services.  This  will  provide  a  clear  demonstration  of  elderly  social  work  and 
community care policy and implementation, including financing, delivery modes, 
human resources development, and monitoring and evaluation. Participants will 
be less than 10 decision makers from central and provincial levels where the TA 
is active. Study tour findings and policy recommendations will be presented in 
workshops. 
 
(ii)  Output 2: Guidelines and broad implementation framework for social work 
service standards for the elderly with special difficulties. The TA will study 
the needs of the elderly with special difficulties, identify and prepare guidelines 
for  relevant  social  work  services  and  their  delivery,  and  prepare  a  broad 
implementation framework to implement the guidelines. Concerned officials of 
the ministry and bureaus of civil affairs will be trained on the guidelines. 
 
(iii)  Output 3: Indicator system for monitoring and evaluation of social work 
services  for  the  elderly  with  special  difficulties. The TA  will  develop  an 
indicator  system,  including  through  stakeholder  consultation  with  central  and 
local government staff, professional social workers, other carers, and a diverse 
range of concerned community and social organizations. The TA will also study 
the  administrative  requirements  and  pilot  test  the  feasibility  of  the  indicator 
system. In addition, it will develop an evaluation system for the ministry and 
bureaus  of  civil  affairs  to  assess  the  effectiveness  of  social  work  services 
programs, including from the perspective of male and female clients. Concerned

4   
officials of the ministry and bureaus of civil affairs will be trained on the indicator 
system. 
 
(iv)  Output 4: Dissemination of findings. Two workshops and a final conference—
with the participation of central and provincial officials, the private sector, and civil 
society stakeholders—will be held to discuss and disseminate TA findings and 
policy recommendations. A knowledge product on social work service standards 
and delivery modes for the elderly with special difficulties will be prepared. A final 
TA report will be submitted to MOCA and ADB. 
 
10.  Potential risks are considered manageable given the high commitment and urgency for 
MOCA to develop national recommendations on strengthening social work services for the 
elderly  with  special  difficulties.  Two  identified  risks  are  (i)  ineffective  coordination  among 
government bodies and with external stakeholders, and (ii) lack of data available to pilot test the 
indicator  system.  Coordination  among  government  bodies  is  required  to  develop  a  set  of 
realistic social work services and indicators, taking into account available financial and human 
resources. This risk will be mitigated by organizing two workshops and a final conference with 
multisector participation. Given the high standing of elderly care on the policy agenda, risk is 
limited for lack of cooperation from other government bodies. Data availability for pilot testing 
the indicator system will require particular attention by MOCA and consultants, and the pilot test 
will be developed in accordance with expected data availability. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing   
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, of which $400,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of in-kind contribution through the provision of office 
accommodation  and  venues for meetings,  counterpart  staff and  allowances,  miscellaneous 
administration expenses, and other in-kind contributions. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  MOCA (Department of Social Work) will be the executing agency for the TA. MOCA will 
designate a senior staff as the TA focal point. The TA will be implemented over 18 months 
tentatively from 1 July 2015 to 31 December 2016. 
 
13.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
14.  In dialogue with MOCA, ADB will engage an international (2 person-months) and four 
national (30 person-months) consultants, who will report to MOCA and ADB. Consultants will be 
hired on an individual basis in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time).9 The senior international consultant will have multi-
country expertise in social work and elderly care planning and implementation, in addition to 
evaluation  expertise  and  demonstrated  writing  skills.  The  national  consultants  will  include 
specialists with expertise in social work development and service outsourcing, assessment of 
elderly care needs, evaluation methods, development of operational guidelines, monitoring and 
evaluation  system  development  and  implementation,  and  administrative  and  finance. 
Consultants’  tasks  and  reporting  requirements  are  in  the  outline  terms  of  reference  for 
                                                
9  Some consultants will be hired as individual consultants through entities (e.g., universities and research centers).

5 
consultants (Appendix 3). Consultant reports will be prepared in Chinese and English. The TA 
will also recruit resource persons (tentatively 10) to support the workshops and final conference. 
 
15.  Regular meetings will be held involving MOCA and concerned provincial bureau officials, 
nongovernment organizations involved in social work, and concerned educational and aging 
institutions.  Dissemination  of  TA  achievements  will  be  ensured  through  two  multisector 
workshops; a bilingual knowledge product on social work service standards and delivery modes 
for the elderly with special difficulties in the PRC, which will be disseminated in hard copy and 
electronically,  including  through  appropriate  PRC  websites;  and  a  final  conference  on  TA 
findings  with  participation  of  provincial,  national,  and  international  experts,  and  associated 
media reporting. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for Social Work Services Policy and Delivery Modes for the 
Elderly with Special Difficulties, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  recruit  an  international  and  four  national 
consultants  on  an  individual  and  intermittent  basis  during  the  technical  assistance  (TA). 
Consultants will be recruited in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2013, as amended from time to time), and will work under the guidance of the Ministry of Civil 
Affairs (MOCA) and ADB. 
 
2.  Senior social work and elderly care specialist (international, 2 person-months). The 
specialist should have a postgraduate degree in social sciences with multicountry expertise in 
social work and elderly care planning and implementation, in addition to evaluation expertise 
and  demonstrated  writing  skills.  Relevant  project  or  research  experience  in  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) and a good command of the Chinese language are desirable. The 
specialist will report to MOCA, ADB, and the team leader, and perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review international literature on social work services for the elderly with special 
difficulties, including from a gender perspective. 
(ii)  Advise  MOCA  and  the  team  leader  on  organizing  an  overseas  trip  for  the 
development, planning, financing, implementation, and monitoring of social work 
services (including through outsourcing to private sector and social organizations, 
and other modalities) for the elderly. 
(iii)  Assist  in  preparing  the  TA  study  report  by  writing  the  section  and 
recommendations  on  international  experience  in  provision  and  guidelines  for 
social work services for the elderly with special difficulties. 
(iv)  Provide regular feedback on the progress made in achieving outputs 2 and 3, 
including reviewing the indicator framework and the final TA report. 
(v)  Prepare a bilingual knowledge product on social work service standards and 
delivery  modes  for  the  elderly  with  special  difficulties  in  the  PRC  and  its 
dissemination plan, in coordination with national consultants. 
 
3.  Senior social work and elderly care specialist and team leader (national, 10 person-
months). The specialist should have a postgraduate degree in social sciences or related fields 
with at least 5 years of relevant experience in social work development, a good understanding 
of elderly care needs, evaluation methods, and proven writing skills; and should be fluent in 
English. The specialist will be the team leader of the group of consultants reporting to MOCA 
and ADB, and will perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Review national and international literature on social work services for the elderly 
with special difficulties, including from a gender perspective. 
(ii)  Review and report on ongoing pilot experiences in social work services for the 
elderly with special difficulties in the PRC, including from a gender perspective. 
(iii)  Carry out relevant field visits in the PRC to study experience on social work 
services for the elderly in close coordination with MOCA. 
(iv)  Arrange  and  carry  out  training  sessions  for  MOCA  and  civil  affairs  bureau 
representatives on the results of outputs 2 and 3, in coordination with other 
consultants. 
(v)  Organize and participate as interpreter and advisor in an overseas trip on the 
development, planning, financing, implementation, and monitoring of social work 
services (including outsourcing to private sector and social organizations) for the 
elderly.

(vii)  Prepare a peer-reviewed study report on national and international experience in 
social work services for the elderly with special difficulties, including broad policy 
recommendations.  The  study  will  also  provide  recommendations  on  how  to 
achieve an affordable and sustainable funding system for care and support in 
different settings.  
(viii)  Prepare the required TA reports (inception, midterm, and final) in English and 
Chinese, with inputs from the other consultants. 
(ix)  Assist in preparing a knowledge product on social work service standards for the 
elderly with special difficulties in the PRC. 
(x)  Prepare and facilitate the dissemination of the required reports, including the final 
TA report and the final policy recommendations to MOCA, with inputs from other 
consultants and under the guidance of MOCA. 
 
4.  Senior social work services expert for elderly care (national, 8 person-months). The 
specialist should have a postgraduate degree in social sciences with substantial experience in 
social  work  services  development,  elderly  care  needs  assessment,  and  preparation  of 
operational guidelines; and should be fluent in English. The specialist will report to MOCA, ADB, 
and the team leader, and perform the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Study the gendered needs of the elderly with special difficulties in the PRC. 
(ii)  Identify relevant social work services to address the needs. 
(iii)  Review and recommend good practices on social work service delivery modes 
(government, outsourced, private sector, and social organizations). 
(iv)  Detail gender-sensitive identified social work services for the elderly with special 
difficulties. 
(v)  Prepare guidelines for social work services (procedures, skills and resources 
required, and performance criteria). 
(vi)  Prepare a broad implementation framework for the social services guidelines 
(reform of social work services training, MOCA preparation, resources, and policy 
and systems changes required). 
(vii)  Provide relevant inputs for the preparation of the required reports, including the 
final TA report. 
(viii)  Contribute to the development of the study report under the responsibility of the 
team leader by providing inputs on social work services for the elderly with 
special difficulties. 
(ix)  Participate in field visits in agreement with MOCA to collect detailed information 
on  national  good  practices  on  social  work  services  that  are  relevant  to  the 
diverse contexts in the PRC.  
(x)  Participate in TA training activities for MOCA and bureau officials. 
(xi)  Participate as resource person in workshops and the final conference. 
 
5.  Senior  monitoring  and  evaluation  expert  for  social  work  services  (national, 
7 person-months). The specialist should have a postgraduate degree in social sciences with 
substantial experience in monitoring and evaluation systems development and implementation, 
and should be fluent in English. The specialist will report to MOCA, ADB, and the team leader, 
and perform the following tasks:

12  Appendix 3 
(i)  Identify information needs of managers, decision makers, and contracted social 
organizations implementing social work services programs for the elderly with 
special difficulties. 
(ii)  Define  indicators,  data-collection  methods,  and  responsibilities  to  answer 
information needs of managers and decision makers (indicator system). 
(iii)  Identify administrative requirements and pilot test the feasibility of the indicator 
system. 
(iv)  Design an evaluation system useful for (a) the ministry and bureaus of civil affairs 
to assess the effectiveness of social work services programs for the elderly with 
special  difficulties,  and  (b)  contracted  social  organizations  to  improve  their 
understanding and delivery practices. The evaluation system will also aim at 
protecting the rights and basic requirements of the elderly with special difficulties. 
(v)  Provide relevant inputs to the preparation of the required reports, including the 
final TA report. 
(vi)  Contribute to the development of the study report under the responsibility of the 
team leader by providing inputs as required. 
(vii)  Participate in TA training activities for officials of the ministry and bureaus of civil 
affairs. 
(viii)  Participate as resource person in workshops and the final conference. 
 
6.  Administrative  and  financial  assistant  (national,  5  person-months). The  assistant 
should have qualifications in administration and finance and 3 years of experience, and should 
be fluent in English. The assistant will report to MOCA, ADB, and the team leader, and perform 
the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assist MOCA in organizing workshops, the final conference, training sessions, 
and logistics for field trips. 
(ii)  Assist  MOCA  in  promptly  administering  ADB  finances  and  prepare  regular 
liquidation reports in line with ADB procedures. 
(iii)  Liaise with ADB’s PRC resident mission and ADB headquarters as required to 
fulfill the tasks. 
 
7.  Resource persons. In addition to the above consultants, the TA will provide resource 
persons (tentatively 10) from academia, civil society, and the private sector to present and 
discuss issues related to social work development in the PRC. The inputs of the resource 
persons  will  enhance  the  quality  of  the  discussion  and  provide  concrete  field  experience, 
especially during the workshops and final conference organized under the TA.
